facts.text: Five different suits were filed against certain defendants on the foot of five different pronotes.
All the five suits were heard together and were decreed by the trial judge.
In respect of two suits the valuation being low the appeals were preferred before the District Judge and in three suits the appeals were filed in the High Court.
The High Court dismissed the appeals vide judgment and decree dated December 22, 1961 in First Appeals Nos. 82, 83 and 84 of 1958.
The learned subordinate judge had found that the suit transactions were genuine and execution on behalf of the firm as well as the passing of consideration had been proved.

The contesting defendants were joint with their uncle Manilal in 1949 and that they were the partners of the firm Surajmal Manilal being members of a trading family, and therefore they were liable to the extent of the assets of the joint family in their hands.
The assessment orders were produced not by the contesting defendants but by the son of Manilal who was the assessee.

legal_issues.text: Whether the assessment orders are admissible in evidence when produced by the assessee himself, despite the bar under Section 54 of the Income Tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reliance placed on assessment orders to decide whether the contesting defendants were the partners of firm Surajmal Manilal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh

court_reasoning.text: Section 54 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 creates a complete bar to production by officials of the Income Tax Department and obliges them to treat records as confidential, but if produced by the assessee waiving privilege, admissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overwhelming weight of authority that assessment orders can be produced by the assessee or his representative-in-interest.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh as it involved directing Commissioner to produce records, not production by assessee himself.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition under s.54 absolute when requiring public servant to produce, not obliterated by waiver in that context.

holdings.text: Assessment orders can be produced and admitted in evidence by the assessee or his representative-in-interest.

precedents_cited.relevance: Statements in income tax returns not admissible against maker or others, nor by secondary evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promatha Nath Pramanick v. Nirode Chandra Ghose
precedents_cited.relevance: Startling if joint assessee permitted use of confidential assessment order against co-assessee.
Return confidential to third parties but maker can have copy for own purposes and produce in court.
Assessment orders producible by assessee or representative-in-interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suraj Narain v. Seth Jhabhu Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment orders producible by assessee or representative-in-interest.
Assessment orders producible by assessee or representative-in-interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Charu Chandra Kundu v. Gurupada Ghosh
precedents_cited.relevance: Prohibition absolute when court directs public servant to produce; not applicable to assessee production.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Creates confidentiality bar for public servants but allows production by assessee waiving privilege.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Secondary evidence of income returns not admissible per some High Courts.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the Orissa High Court's dismissal of appeals against the trial court's decree on pronotes are dismissed, upholding the admissibility of assessment orders produced by the assessee.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "the law laid down by these cases on the admissibility of evidence of assessment orders produced by an assessee or his representative-in-interest is unexceptionable."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There is an overwhelming weight of authority in favour of the view that assessment orders could be produced by the assessee or his representative-in-interest"
key_quotes.speaker: court
